Package software.leonov.common.base

Class Str

  • java.lang.Object
    • software.leonov.common.base.Str
  • public final class Str
extends Object
    Static utility methods that operate on or return Strings.

    All methods in this class are expected to throw NullPointerExceptions when given null arguments unless they are specifically documented as being null safe.

    Throughout this class the exact definition of whitespace may change depending on which method is invoked. Each method clearly documents what constitutes as a whitespace character. See a comparison of several definitions of whitespace.

    Author:
    Zhenya Leonov
    See Also:
    Strings, CharMatcher, Joiner, Splitter

        Note: This method uses the rules of the default locale.

        substr - the string to search for
        Returns:
        true if str contains the substr, ignoring case differences, false otherwise
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if either str or substr is null

      • escapeEOLCharacters

        Returns the specified string with line feed \n (U+000A) and carriage return \r (U+000D) characters escaped.
        Parameters:
        str - the specified string
        Returns:
        the specified string with line feed \n (U+000A) and carriage return \r (U+000D) characters escaped

      • indent

        public static String indent​(CharSequence chars,
                            int count)
        Returns a string with the indentation of each line in the specified character sequence adjusted.

        If count > 0 then the specified number of spaces (U+0020) are inserted at the start of each line.
        If count < 0 then up to specified number of CharMatcher.whitespace() characters are removed from the start of each line.
        If count == 0 then no changes are made.

        If any changes are made all line terminators will be normalized to the \n (U+000A) character.

        Note: This method has subtle differences from its Java 12 counterpart String.indent(int):

        • This method does not normalize line terminators if count is 0, while String.indent(int) always normalizes all line terminators.
        • This method uses CharMatcher.whitespace() to recognize whitespace characters, while String.indent(int) uses Character.isWhitespace(int).
        • This method does not append the \n (U+000A) character to the last line in the character sequence, while String.indent(int) does.
        Parameters:
        chars - the specified character sequence
        count - number of leading whitespace characters to add (n > 0) or remove (n < 0)
        Returns:
        a string with adjusted indentation of every line

      • indexOfIgnoreCase

        public static int indexOfIgnoreCase​(String str,
                                    String substr)
        Returns the index within str of the first occurrence of substr, ignoring case differences.

        Note: This method uses the rules of the default locale.

        Parameters:
        str - the specified string
        substr - the string to search for
        Returns:
        the index within str of the first occurrence of substr, ignoring case differences
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if either str or substr is null

      • indexOfIgnoreCase

        public static int indexOfIgnoreCase​(String str,
                                    String substr,
                                    int fromIndex)
        Returns the index within str of the first occurrence of substr, starting at the specified index and ignoring case differences.

        Note: This method uses the rules of the default locale.

        Parameters:
        str - the specified string
        substr - the string to search for
        fromIndex - the index from which to start the search
        Returns:
        the index within str of the first occurrence of substr, ignoring case differences
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if fromIndex < 0
        StringIndexOutOfBoundsException - if fromIndex > the length of str
        NullPointerException - if either str or substr is null

      • isNullOrWhitespace

        public static boolean isNullOrWhitespace​(CharSequence chars)
        Returns true if the specified character sequence is null, empty, or contains only whitespace characters.

        This method is null safe.

        Parameters:
        chars - the specified character sequence or null
        Returns:
        true if the specified character sequence is null, empty, or contains only whitespace characters, false otherwise
        See Also:
        CharMatcher.whitespace(), Strings.isNullOrEmpty(String), Strings.nullToEmpty(String), Object.toString()

        Returns true if the specified character sequence is empty or contains only whitespace characters.

        Java 11 counterpart: String.isBlank()

        Parameters:
        chars - the specified character sequence
        Returns:
        true if the specified character sequence is empty or contains only whitespace characters, false otherwise
        See Also:
        CharMatcher.whitespace(), Strings.isNullOrEmpty(String), Strings.nullToEmpty(String), Object.toString()

      • readLines

        public static List<String> readLines​(CharSequence chars)
        Returns all the lines read from a character sequence. The lines do not include line-termination characters, but do include other leading and trailing whitespace.

        Java 11 counterpart: String.lines()

        Parameters:
        chars - the character sequence to read from
        Returns:
        a mutable List containing all the lines read from a character sequence

      • remove

        public static String remove​(String str,
                            String substr)
        Removes all instances of the specified substring from the given string.

        Note: Users of Java 6, Java 7, and Java 8 should prefer this method to String.replace because it avoids the expensive cost of using the java.util.regex facility. Java 9+ users can call String.replace which has a faster implementation and avoids using java.util.regex. See JDK-8058779 Issue for more information.

        Parameters:
        str - the specified string
        substr - the substring to remove
        Returns:
        the given string with all instances of the specified substring removed

      • removeIgnoreCase

        public static String removeIgnoreCase​(String str,
                                      String substr)
        Removes all instances of the specified substring from the given string, ignoring case differences.
        Parameters:
        str - the specified string
        substr - the substring to remove
        Returns:
        the given string with all instances of the specified substring removed, ignoring case differences

      • replace

        public static String replace​(String str,
                             String substr,
                             String replacement)
        Replaces all instances of the specified substring in the given string with the replacement string.

        Note: Users of Java 6, Java 7, and Java 8 should prefer this method to String.replace(CharSequence, CharSequence) because it avoids the expensive cost of using the java.util.regex facility. Java 9+ users can call String.replace(CharSequence, CharSequence) which has a faster implementation and avoids using java.util.regex. See JDK-8058779 Issue for more information.

        Parameters:
        str - the specified string
        substr - the substring to replace
        replacement - the replacement string
        Returns:
        the given string with all instances of the specified substring replaced with the replacement string

        substr - the substring to replace
        replacement - the replacement string
        Returns:
        the given string with all instances of the specified substring replaced with the replacement string, ignoring case differences

      • replaceSupplementaryCharacters

        public static String replaceSupplementaryCharacters​(CharSequence chars)
        Returns the given character sequence with the set of characters from U+0000 to U+FFFF (outside the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP) characters) replaced with the U+FFFD (� ) character.

        This method is useful when you need to pass a UTF-8 encoded string to a consumer that only supports one to three bytes per character.

        Parameters:
        chars - the given character sequence
        Returns:
        the given character sequence with the set of characters from U+0000 to U+FFFF (outside the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP) characters) replaced with the U+FFFD (� ) character

      • replaceSupplementaryCharacters

        public static String replaceSupplementaryCharacters​(CharSequence chars,
                                                    char replacement)
        Returns the given character sequence with the set of characters from U+0000 to U+FFFF (outside the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP) characters) replaced with the specified character.

        This method is useful when you need to pass a UTF-8 encoded string to a consumer that only supports one to three bytes per character.

        Parameters:
        chars - the given character sequence
        replacement - the character to use when replacing characters outside the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP)
        Returns:
        the given character sequence with the set of characters from U+0000 to U+FFFF (outside the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP) characters) replaced with the specified character

      • trim

        public static String trim​(CharSequence chars)
        Returns a copy of the specified character sequence, with trailing and leading whitespace omitted.

        This method is null safe.

        Java 11 counterpart: String.strip()

        Parameters:
        chars - the specified character sequence or null
        Returns:
        a copy of the specified character sequence, with trailing and leading whitespace omitted or null
        See Also:
        trimStart(CharSequence), trimEnd(CharSequence), trimLines(CharSequence)

      • trimEnd

        public static String trimEnd​(CharSequence chars)
        Returns a copy of the specified character sequence, with trailing whitespace omitted.

        This method is null safe.

        Java 11 equivalent: String.stripTrailing()

        Parameters:
        chars - the specified character sequence or null
        Returns:
        a copy of the specified character sequence, with trailing whitespace omitted or null
        See Also:
        trim(CharSequence), trimStart(CharSequence), trimLines(CharSequence)

      • trimLines

        public static String trimLines​(CharSequence chars)
        Returns a copy of the specified character sequence, with leading and trailing blank lines omitted. A blank line is defined as containing only whitespace characters according to the predefined character class \s which matches [ \t\n\x0B\f\r] in the java.util.regex facility.

        This method is null safe.

        Parameters:
        chars - the specified character sequence or null
        Returns:
        a copy of the specified character sequence, with leading and trailing blank lines omitted or null
        See Also:
        trim(CharSequence), trimStart(CharSequence), trimEnd(CharSequence)

      • trimStart

        public static String trimStart​(CharSequence chars)
        Returns a copy of the specified character sequence, with leading whitespace omitted.

        This method is null safe.

        Java 11 equivalent: String.stripLeading()

        Parameters:
        chars - the specified character sequence or null
        Returns:
        a copy of the specified character sequence, with leading whitespace whitespace or null
        See Also:
        trim(CharSequence), trimEnd(CharSequence), trimLines(CharSequence)

      • truncate

        public static String truncate​(CharSequence chars,
                              int maxLength)
        Returns the given character sequence truncated to the specified maximum length.

        If the length of the given sequence is greater than maxLength, the returned string will be exactly maxLength in length. Otherwise the sequence will be returned as a String with no changes.

        This method is null safe.

        Parameters:
        chars - the given character sequence or null
        maxLength - the specified maximum length
        Returns:
        the given character sequence truncated to the specified maximum length or null
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if maxLength < 1

      • truncate

        public static String truncate​(CharSequence chars,
                              int maxLength,
                              String suffix)
        Returns the given character sequence truncated to the specified maximum length.

        If the length of the given sequence is greater than maxLength, the returned string will be exactly maxLength in length and will end with suffix (if it is not null). Otherwise the sequence will be returned as a String with no changes.

        This method is null safe.

        Parameters:
        chars - the given character sequence or null
        maxLength - the specified maximum length
        suffix - the string to append to the truncated sequence or null for no suffix
        Returns:
        the given character sequence truncated to the specified maximum length or null
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if maxLength < 1
        IllegalArgumentException - if suffix is not null and its length is not less than maxLength

      • whitespaceToNull

        public static <T extends CharSequence> T whitespaceToNull​(T chars)
        Returns null if the given character sequence is null, empty, or contains only whitespace characters, otherwise the original character sequence is returned.

        This method is null safe.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of CharSequence (typically CharSequence or a String)
        Parameters:
        chars - the specified character sequence or null
        Returns:
        null if the given character sequence is null, empty, or contains only whitespace characters
